International Student Affairs Office
Admitted Students
Home / Admitted Students
Congratulations on your admission to the University of Missouri – Kansas City! We are excited that you have selected UMKC to pursue your higher education goals. We look forward to welcoming you to Kansas City.
ADMITTED STUDENTS
Student Visa
Pre-Arrival Information
Official Documents
Financial Information
Check-in Session
Student Housing
Health Insurance
UMKC Connections
You've been accepted to UMKC. What are your next steps?
  1. Admission letter
You will receive an email letting you know that an update has been made to your application status. A link in that email will take you to your application status page where you'll find your official admission letter. If you are (or will be) an F-1 or J-1 student visa holder, this is also where you will find your supporting documents for your visa application. (It may take a couple of weeks after admission before your immigration documents will be uploaded and attached to your admission letter.)
Learn more about pre-arrival
  2. U.S. student visa
If you will need an F-1 or J-1 student visa to travel to the U.S. for your studies, your next step is to start the visa application process.
Learn more about your student visa
If you are experiencing a delay in scheduling an appointment for a visa, let us know so we can help with late arrival or admission deferral.
  Transferring your immigration record to UMKC
If you are already studying at another US institution on an F-1 visa, or if you entered the US on another school's I-20, you will need to complete the UMKC Transfer-in form and upload it as a document in your application portal.
Transfer-in form (PDF)


3. Check-in session
This step is only for students who will attend UMKC with an F-1 or J-1 student visa.
Once you have obtained your visa, you will need to pre-register for an immigration check-in session with our international advising team. Attendance at this in-person check-in session is required once you've arrived in the United States. You will need to register for your mandatory check-in session and submit a copy of your F-1 or J-1 visa in order to enroll in classes.
Learn more about the Check-In Session
  Submit these documents before you attend your scheduled session
Signed UMKC I-20 or DS-2019
A copy of your I-94 form (this will only be available to you after you've arrived to the U.S.)
Final, official transcripts and certificates of completion, if they have not yet been submitted
Please arrive for your session 15 minutes in advance. Late entry is not permitted.
  4. Enroll in classes
After you have registered for your check-in session, you will be eligible to meet with your academic advisor who will help you select classes. Enroll in classes through your academic advisor, the Office of the Registrar or through your Pathway student account.
  Undergraduate academic advising
New undergraduate students must complete a pre-enrollment survey in order to get enrolled in their first semester at UMKC. The link to this survey will be added to your Pre-Arrival Checklist within your application portal. For F-1 and J-1 students, this survey will only be available to you after you've registered for your check-in session and uploaded a copy of your student visa (step #3 above).
Undergraduates: Connect with Roo Advising
  Graduate academic advising
Most new UMKC students are required to meet with an advisor prior to registering for classes in their first semester. Depending on your major, you may be required to meet with your academic advisor prior to registering for classes each semester through your degree program.
Learn more about academic advising
  5. Attend International Student Orientation
All new international students are required to attend Orientation in their first semester. Orientation is typically held on the Thursday prior to the start of classes each fall and spring. You will receive more information about this exciting event as you get closer to the start of your first semester!
Registration will soon be available for Fall 2024 International New Student Orientation! this required orientation will be held on Thursday, August 15, 2024. If you are a new international student for Fall 2024, you will receive an email inviting you to register when the registration page is available.
  6. Submit Your Official Documents
You must submit your Official Documents (transcripts/degree certificates, official test scores as applicable) by the end of your first semester at UMKC. If you do not submit your Official Documents, you will not be able to enroll in your second semester.
We do not accept physical documents. Please read our Official Documents Policy for complete information on how to submit your documents.

International Student Affairs Office
Exchange Visitors
Home / Exchange Visitors
The work- and study-based Exchange Visitor program promotes global understanding through cultural and educational exchanges. We welcome exchange visitors from around the world and are committed to enriching their professional development and academic goals.
EXCHANGE VISITORS
J-1 Exchange Scholar Categories
Hosting an Exchange Visitor
Exchange Visitor Responsibilities and Forms
Exchange Visitor (J-1) Nonimmigrant Visa
The Exchange Visitor (J-1) nonimmigrant visa category is for individuals approved to participate in work- and study-based exchange visitor programs. Participants in the Exchange Visitor program are expected to return to their home countries after they have completed their programs to share their exchange experiences. 
View eligibility and fees
Learn about the program
What documentation do I need?
Form DS-2019 is a Certificate of Eligibility for Exchange Visitor (J-1) status. When you have been offered acceptance into an exchange program at UMKC, an immigration advisor in the International Student Affairs Office will issue a DS-2019. Upon receipt of the DS-2019, you can begin the application process for the J-1 visa and the nearest U.S. embassy or consulate in your country of residence.
Pay I-901 SEVIS fee

International Student Affairs Office
Sponsored Students
Home / Sponsored Students
A sponsored student is any student who has received a scholarship from their home government(s) or is funded by other third-party sponsors.
SPONSORED STUDENTS
Kuwait
Oman
Saudi Arabia
Sponsor Information
Sponsored Student Responsibilities
Sponsored students receive scholarships, so there are rules and responsibilities that come along with being a sponsored student.
You must provide ISAO a copy of these documents.
Financial Guarantee from your sponsoring agency
Consent Form, filled out during your check-in session
Insurance Waiver (PDF), if your sponsoring agency provides insurance coverage
Scholarship requirements
When you meet with an academic advisor at UMKC to schedule your courses, you need to make sure your academic advisor is aware that you are a sponsored student and have to abide by specific scholarship requirements. You are responsible for enrolling in courses that are approved by your sponsoring agency. If you complete courses that are not approved by your sponsoring agency, you will be expected to pay for those courses.
Courses that may not be approved by your sponsoring agency.
Online courses
PACE courses
Accelerated courses
Weekend and evening courses
Courses outside your major area of study
Language courses in a language you are already fluent in
If you are unsure whether or not your sponsoring agency will cover courses, reach out to your advisor at your sponsoring agency and confirm whether your courses are approved.
Additional requirements
Agencies in some countries have additional requirements.
Kuwait
Oman 
Saudi Arabia

UNIVERSITY OF MISSOURI-KANSAS CITY
search

International Student Affairs Office
Life in Kansas City
Home / Life in Kansas City
We believe that your involvement and interactions with other residents of the Kansas City community are valuable and beneficial experiences. We encourage you to explore the city and enjoy everything it has to offer.
2.3
Million people
The number of people living in the metropolitan area ranks Kansas City as the largest city in Missouri, making it the largest city in Missouri, the sixth largest city in the Midwest and the 37th most populated city in the United States.
9
Fortune 1000 companies
Kansas City is home to several global companies, including three on the Fortune 500 list. This is where many startups get their start, too. Our proximity to health care, technology, manufacturing and finance provides opportunities for exciting internships and careers.
2.5%
Cost of living below the national average
That's how much further your dollars can go here than in some other U.S. cities. Combined with an employment rate above the national average, Kansas City is an extremely affordable place to live and even raise a family.
The Center of It All
Known for its friendly people, affordable prices and central location, Kansas City — affectionately called KC — has a welcoming energy. It's a place with both a creative spirit and a genuine heart. It's a breath of fresh air and a city with room to breathe. Let us show you KC.
Something for Everyone
KC is experiencing a creative revolution — in food, art, business and technology. We're welcoming new people and new ideas, making the city an exciting place to be.
Arts
Creativity thrives in Kansas City. We're home to internationally known museums, dynamic gallery districts and celebrated musical and theatrical performances. Several celebrated companies, including the Lyric Opera of Kansas City, the Kansas City Symphony and the Kansas City Ballet, have been captivating audiences in Kansas City for decades.
Sports
American football, baseball, hockey and race-car driving teams have all made their home in Kansas City, but we're quickly becoming known as the U.S. soccer capital. Two-time MLS Cup champions Sporting Kansas City play here, and we recently broke ground on the first soccer stadium built for women's soccer in the United States. We're even hosting FIFA World Cup 2026!
Gaming
With the introduction of major advancements in fiber and internet technologies, Kansas City has grown into a hub for players, fans and content creators. In fact, a recent online survey ranked Kansas City as the second-best city across the United States and Canada for gamers. We also boast our own LEGOLAND Discovery Center and Planet Comicon and plenty of arcades, VR game rooms and other fun activities and events.
The New Midwest
The New Midwest represents a fresh spirit, a reimagination of the region at its finest. And it all starts right here in Kansas City.
Watch the Visit KC video

12
Schools
More opportunities to focus on your particular interests as well as experience cross-disciplinary study
125+
Academic areas
With this many areas of study, you're sure to find the program that fits your goals.
60+
Graduate degrees
Our graduate programs at the master's, doctoral and professional levels, can set you on the path to a successful career.
Find Your Program
Ignite new interests, strengthen your talents and start your path to a rewarding career at Kansas City's only public urban research university.
Search
All Programs Apply Now
About UMKC Academics
First-name basis
Our professors are world class but still accessible and approachable. In many courses, professors expect the students to ask questions and actively participate in class. Students pursuing advanced degrees are particularly encouraged to critique theories, formulate models and interact with the professor.
Global influence
In addition to our many international students, our faculty members also come from all over the world, with a wide range of experience and expertise.
Hands-on experience
Classes sometimes include a practical as well as a theoretical component. Lectures account for the theoretical, and workshops, labs and study groups make up the practical, which may include hands-on projects.
Explore Our Programs
No matter your area of interest, our undergraduate and graduate programs cultivate skills in analysis, critical thinking, writing and communication and the principles of science and engineering for a truly interdisciplinary education.

Employment
Home / Current Students / Employment
Many international students work part- or full-time while studying in Kansas City. We're here to help you navigate the employment process.
On-Campus Employment
Authorization for part-time employment on the UMKC campus is available. Professional skills increase your chances of landing a job.
Search for jobs
Off-Campus Employment
Holders of F-1 and J-1 visas may work off-campus if they have verifiable, legal permission for employment. You may apply for employment permission after you have completed one full academic year of study in your degree field (not including English as a Second Language).
I-9 form
Stating incorrect information on your I-9 is considered fraud and could result in the denial of benefits or change of status. If you are unsure about how to answer a question, consult your employer’s human resources (HR) office for clarification.

Drop-In Advising
For questions that take less than 10 minutes to answer, please join us at our Virtual Welcome Desk or at the ISAO office at the following times:
Mondays 3–4 p.m. - via Virtual Welcome Desk
Tuesdays  3–4 p.m. - at ISAO
Thursdays 10–11 a.m. - at ISAO
Fridays 10–11 a.m. - via Virtual Welcome Desk
Virtual Welcome Desk 
For Virtual Drop-Ins:
Only one person from the waiting room is allowed in the meeting at a time. Please be patient until a member of our Welcome Center lets you into the meeting.
You will be asked for a summary of your question. If it will take longer than 10 minutes to answer your question, you’ll be directed to schedule an appointment with an advisor.

International Student Affairs Office
International Ambassadors
Home / About Us / International Ambassadors
Who We Are
The UMKC International Student Ambassador Program (ISAP) consists of selectively chosen international and domestic students to serve as official university diplomats. International Ambassadors are available to act as hosts at a variety of university events, as guides to university visitors and prospective students and as the primary contact for admitted students regarding questions about UMKC, Kansas City or the United States. They also serve as an aid to new international students in the transition process from their home country to the United States and UMKC.
Questions for our International Ambassadors?
Send an email or start a chat here on this page!  
Are you interested in becoming an International Ambassador?
The call for new International Ambassadors is put out at the start of the spring semester each year. You can read more about the application process, including eligibility requirements, responsibilities, and participation requirements, by viewing the PDF linked below.
ISAP Call for Applications 2024
Applications to become an International Ambassador for the 2024-2025 school year are now CLOSED! Applications for the 2025-2026 school year will open Spring 2024.
(CLOSED) Apply HERE        Letter of Recommendation Form Submission
  Meet Our International Ambassadors
Adriana Martinez Cappello
Lead Ambassador
Fall 2024 Live Chat: Mondays 8-9 AM, Wednesdays 8-10 AM, Thursdays 9-10 AM
Venezuela
MS Mathematics
Hola! Bienvenidos a UMKC! My name is Adriana and I am from Caracas, Venezuela! I have been in the States since 2018; I did my Computer Science, Mathematics, and Statistics undergrad here at UMKC in 2023. Currently, I am pursuing my master's in mathematics. I love the beach, coloring, practicing hot yoga, and reading. Please say hi or hola if you see me around!
Keerti Bajaj
Financial Coordinator
Fall 2024 Live Chat: Wednesdays 10-2 PM
India
iPhD Computer Science
Hola… aloha… everyone! My name is Keerti Bajaj. I am from Hyderabad, India (the place where the famous "DUM BIRYANI" comes from). I moved around many places in and out of India to study, explore, experience and spread wings across. I came here to Kansas City, to UMKC, in Fall 2021. I really fell in love with the place, it has great places, people and vibe!
I like exploring new places, food and meeting strangers to making friends. I absolutely love cooking, it’s Zen. If I weren’t doing what I am now, I would be a chef. I love fantasies and theories, and I made so many of them personally! I’m always curious to try everything that’s new to me, learn it and just gain new skills.
I prefer sunrises over sunsets (both are equally beautiful, just what they mean individually to me). I love star gazing, any place with pretty lights (such as downtown), long drives and long walks are some of the things I do to get out of my tiring schedule. If you are reading this, I "REALLY" look forward to meeting you sometime on campus!!
Victor Olantunji
Programming Coordinator
Fall 2024 Live Chat: Mondays 2-5 PM, Tuesdays 4-5 PM
Nigeria
BS Computer Science
Hello everyone! My name is Victor Olatunji, and I'm excited to serve as an International Student Ambassador at the University of Missouri-Kansas City (UMKC) this year. As a Computer Science student, I have a passion for coding, cybersecurity, artificial intelligence, and all things tech related.
While I am Nigerian by nationality courtesy of my parents, my life has been a global adventure. Born in Malawi, I spent my early years in Mozambique before moving to Kenya for schooling. This diverse upbringing has allowed me to immerse myself in different cultures, an experience I'm incredibly grateful for. 
At UMKC, I've actively engaged in various clubs and organizations, fostering lifelong friendships and personal growth beyond academics. When I'm not studying, I enjoy playing, watching, or gaming related to football (soccer), table tennis, reading, exploring new cuisines, traveling, and spending quality time with friends. 
One of the highlights of my UMKC experience has been connecting with people from diverse backgrounds while also building a sense of community with fellow international students. Participating in campus events has been a fantastic way to do this. 
As an International Student Ambassador, I'm eager to share my experiences, inspire others, and provide support to fellow students. I believe UMKC offers fertile ground for everyone to reach their full potential, and I'm excited to be part of that journey with you. 
I look forward to welcoming you to the UMKC community and building connections. Please don't hesitate to reach out with any questions or just to chat. I can't wait to see what we can accomplish together!
Hanan Jan
Programming Coordinator
Fall 2023 Live Chat: Mondays 2-5 PM, Tuesdays 4-5 PM
Saudi Arabia and Pakistan
BSC Mathematics and Statistics
Hey! I'm Hanan, from Gilgit Baltistan, in the northern areas of Pakistan. I was born and raised in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.
I love playing games in my free time and have been part of the KC Esports team for Overwatch since the Fall of 2023. Another fun fact about me is that I'm interested in learning more languages!
I tend to spend most of my days on campus, so don't be scared to come up and say hi!
Prajwal Rasaily
Culture Fest Coordinator
Fall 2024 Live Chat: Wednesdays 1:30-4 PM, Fridays 8-9:30 AM
Nepal
MS Accounting, Business Analytics
Namaste, Roos and everyone! I am Prajwal Rasaily from the beautiful land of the Himalayas, Nepal. I am pursuing a Master of Science in Accounting degree with a Graduate Certificate in Business Analytics at the Henry Bloch School of Management. 
Coming to UMKC has been one of the best decisions of my life. Although I left the comfort of my home in Nepal, UMKC provided me with the support, love, and care that made me feel at home. The community here is incredibly welcoming and always ready to support—you just have to reach out! 
As an international student who has navigated the challenges of adjusting to a new country, I understand what you might be going through. Please feel free to connect with me if you need any assistance or just someone to talk to. You can often find me in Bloch Heritage Hall, where I work as a Graduate Assistant, or around Miller Nichols Library. 
UMKC is not just a place where you gain academic knowledge; you gain a nurturing environment that helps you grow personally and professionally. Don’t just take my word for it—come and experience the supportive and transformative atmosphere of UMKC for yourself.  
A fun fact about me: I love to cook, no matter how tight my schedule is. I always find a way to modify recipes and make dishes presentable and delicious. I look forward to meeting you and sharing the wonderful experiences UMKC has to offer! GO ROOS!
Shahla Daneshmehr
Culture Fest Coordinator
Fall 2024 Live Chat: Fridays 10:30-1 PM, 2-3:30 PM
Iran
iPhD Natural Sciences
I’m a Turkish-Iranian international student ambassador working on an Interdisciplinary doctorate in Natural Sciences, focusing on the connections between, chemistry, physics, and biology. Being multilingual and having a rich cultural background helps me connect easily with people from different cultures.
In addition to my academic interests, I enjoy cooking and am known for making Kufte-Tabrizi (Tabriz meatballs), a famous dish from my homeland. Imagine a meatball with a boiled egg, dried apricot, and walnut inside—it’s amazing and super delicious!
As an international student ambassador, I’m excited to help others feel welcome and supported. I believe that a diverse community makes our campus special, and I’m here to make sure everyone feels included and at home. Whether it’s through conversation, cultural exchange, or just being a friendly face, I’m dedicated to making a positive impact on our community.
I truly look forward to meeting you sometime on campus!
Raza Hussain Khoso
Marketing Coordinator
Fall 2024 Live Chat: Mondays 9-1 PM
Pakistan
MBA Business Analytics
Dhaz Dhaz Dhaz! Asalam u Alikum Everyone. Sab Se Phele Toh Apne Ghabrana Nahi Hai! My name is Raza Hussain Khoso. I am from Karachi, Pakistan. Karachi is called the “City of Lights” and the city which never sleeps. I completed my undergraduate degree from Pakistan and ended up getting a Silver Medal & Gold Medal for being the high achiever. Now I have been here at UMKC since 2023, and I really love it. I am pursuing my master’s with the goal of exploring new cultures and being able to experience exciting journey. I am an extrovert and social individual. 🤪
I like traveling, food and making new friends. I love cooking. I am a chef now. That was my first time out of my home country (I haven’t traveled much but would love to do it in future.). My time at UMKC has been filled with some amazing memories. One of the things I absolutely love about UMKC is its rich diversity and inclusive community. A little fun fact about me: I love networking, making connections and helping others no matter what the situation is.
Outside of academics, I'm involved in different organizations that help me improve my interpersonal skills. I am a President at UMKC Data Analytics and AIESEC in UMKC. I love being outdoors and exploring new surroundings, but I also love staying in and watching Netflix, a mix of being with friends, music, board games and trying new foods.
You can see me everywhere on campus like the ASSC, Library, Bloch School, Student Union and especially in the Swinney because I like sports, play badminton and gym enthusiast so if you want to play Badminton, find me there. If you see me anywhere on campus and need help, say Hi! What I want you to know is that I am here for you. If you want to talk about anything, whether you have a million zillion questions about UMKC, or just to have a chill conversation.
As an International Student Ambassador, my goal is to share my UMKC journey, inspire others, and provide support and guidance to fellow students. I believe that every student at UMKC has the potential to thrive and make the most of their time here, just as I have cherished my past year at this exceptional institution.
Let’s begin the show Roos! 🐾
Raza!

Social Media Coordinator

Somali-American

Hey guys!
My name is Sumeya Geelle and I'm excited to be on the journey ahead of being your international student ambassador J I was born and raised in Kansas City but however moved to Kenya in 2019, but I’m ethnically Somali. I attended a British International University there for about 3 years and then returned to the States. Yes, I know you’re wondering, I did in fact pick up on the British accent which I really wish I stuck to L  I came to UMKC on an International Business Administration route for my undergrad (which UMKC doesn’t provide) however I later switched to marketing.
Something I really enjoy is skincare, shopping & watching new dramas. I’m also a rising football (soccer) fan. I've been traveling a lot lately, which helps with my major. I am experiencing an uncanny feeling of being Emily in Paris. Everyone's interests are catered to by the wide range of activities and events in Kansas City, which is awesome and fun to discover, in my opinion. I also love meeting new people from different backgrounds. In summary, my position as an international student ambassador is to help close the cultural gap that exists between all of you and the potential cultural shock that some of you might encounter.  Creating a welcoming environment is my top priority & please don’t hesitate to reach out to me on any and everything whether it be a coffee date or questions about how to get over obstacles! 💌
Nonetheless, I’m excited to meet everyone and get to know you all.
Have a great semester & Roo Up!! 🦘

International Student Affairs Office
Student Visa
Home / Admitted Students / Student Visa
ADMITTED STUDENTS
Student Visa
Pre-Arrival Information
Official Documents
Financial Information
Check-in Session
Student Housing
Health Insurance
UMKC Connections
Applying for a U.S. Student Visa
1. Print your I-20 or DS-2019 and sign the first page
2. Pay the SEVIS I-901 fee
All individuals applying for a student visa pay the I-901 fee unless they have paid it with a recent prior admission
The payment receipt is proof of your payment
Pay fee
3. Complete visa application form DS-160
Contact the U.S. embassy or consulate in your country for visa application information required for your country
U.S. student visas may take up to four to six weeks to process
Schedule an interview up to 120 days before the start date of your program
Fill out visa application
4. Go to the embassy or consulate or follow the mailing instructions to apply for a student visa
Bring or mail these items
The printed and signed I-20 or DS-2019 form and your UMKC admission letter
The nonrefundable visa application fee (Follow payment instructions on the form)
A passport valid for at least six months beyond your intended stay in the United States
Photo measuring 22mm x 35mm (if your photo upload failed when submitting the DS-160)
Original school transcripts, diplomas, degrees or certificates, and any copies of any test scores submitted as a part of your admission (TOEFL, IELTS, GRE, etc.)
Copy of completed statement of finances (PDF)
Evidence that demonstrates strong ties to your country or any other residence outside of the United States
Tips for Applying for a Student Visa
You must prove that you have sufficient money to cover the cost of your education. At your interview, you may present the statement of finances (PDF) you sent to UMKC.
You should be able to articulate a clear educational goal to the visa officer.
Include why you chose UMKC over other institutions. Reasons may include degree programs or research options; financial assistance; low cost of living expenses and tuition; a friend who is currently enrolled or you know or want to work with a faculty or staff member from UMKC
Include your long-term goals as they relate to career potential in your home country (or elsewhere outside of the United States). If the consular official believes that it is your intent to immigrate to the United States rather than return to your country after your studies are completed, your visa may be denied. The F-1 and J-1 visas are non-immigrant visas, so hopes for immigration to the United States is one of the major reasons for visa denials.
Do not get discouraged if you are denied a visa. If you are denied a visa, the consular official will notify you in writing regarding the reason. You may reapply for a student visa when you can submit the needed items or documentation.
If you need more time to apply for a visa, you may defer your admission.

International Student Affairs Office
Application Documents
Home / Future Students / Application Documents
The first step to becoming a student at UMKC is completing the application for admission and submitting the required documents required for admission consideration.
FUTURE STUDENTS
Application Documents
Affordability and Funding
English Proficiency
Scholarships
Transfer Credit
Chat with our student ambassadors
Required Documents
Please upload your application documents directly to your online application. These can be submitted while you are filling out the application or after you submit your application.
1. Academic records
Upload PDFs of your academic records — transcripts, mark sheets, diplomas and degree certificates — to your application portal. Once you have been admitted, you will have until the end of your first semester at UMKC to submit official academic records.
Learn more about submitting official academic records
2. Proof of English proficiency
Proof of English proficiency is not required for these applicants.
Citizens of countries that have English as an official language (PDF)
Students who have completed Composition I and II courses with a grade of C or better at a U.S. accredited university or college
Students who have earned a degree or at least 24 credit hours of non-ESL coursework at an accredited university or college in the United States, Canada, United Kingdom, New Zealand or Australia
Students who have successfully completed high school in the United States at an accredited school
All other applicants may demonstrate proof of English proficiency by providing a qualifying score needed for their program from one of the accepted tests. Official test scores must be sent to UMKC directly from the testing center.
Learn more about proof of English proficiency
3. Supplemental materials
Required supplemental materials may include GRE (reporting code 6872) or GMAT test scores, supplemental applications, personal statement, resume and writing samples. Verify additional requirements with your academic department. Official test scores must be sent to UMKC directly from the testing center.
4. Passport
Submit a copy of your passport photo page.
5. Statement of finances
Students with an F-1 or J-1 visa are required to provide a statement of finances as proof they are able to afford full-time study for at least one academic year (August through May) before they receive their I-20 or DS-2019.
View cost estimates
Follow the Financial Statement Guidelines (PDF)
  If we are unable to verify your financial documents through our own efforts, UMKC ISAO will request your permission to verify them through our partner agency Veri Once. The only step you should take is to reply to our request to inform us whether you approve. If you provide approval by email, UMKC ISAO will request and pay for the verification for you. Please do not undertake any verification steps through other means as we do not accept verification from other sources.
6. Affidavit of support
If a friend or family member is providing a statement of finances, they will need to submit an affidavit of support indicating that they agree to sponsor your studies. 
View Affidavit of Support Form (PDF)
7. Immigration documents
Students currently in the U.S. should submit a copy of their immigrant or non-immigrant status documents, such as a visa or I-797. Students currently at another U.S. institution in F or J status should submit a copy of their visa, I-94, and I-20 ("Continued Attendance") or DS-2019.

Transfer Credit
Chat with our student ambassadors
UMKC accepts credit transferred from regionally accredited institutions in the United States and Ministry of Education-approved institutions outside of the United States. Transfer work will not be posted to your UMKC academic record until official transcripts are received. Transfer work is only posted for students working toward their first bachelor’s degree.
Learn more about transfer credit
Undergraduate students who have graduated from high schools in countries where the language of instruction is not English may also receive foreign language credit for their native languages.
Evaluating transcripts for transfer credit
All undergraduate college coursework attempted at recognized institutions will be recorded on the UMKC transcript of students seeking an undergraduate degree, regardless of whether it is applicable to a UMKC degree. Credit accepted from another institution may or may not be applicable to specific degree programs. The university reserves the right to make the decision regarding applicability.
Remedial courses will not be added to the total hours or used to satisfy degree requirements. The Registrar’s Office will refer to the transcript key or catalog of the sending institution in making a determination as to the level or purpose of the course in question.
Transferred courses will be considered upper-division (junior-senior level) and count toward the total number of upper-division hours required if they are earned at a four-year institution and designated by that institution’s course numbering system as upper-division courses.
A course transferred from an accredited U.S. institution will retain the original number of credit hours for which it was taken at the previous institution, even if the equivalent UMKC course is worth a different number of hours.
A course transferred from a recognized international institution will be converted by ISAO staff into U.S.-based Carnegie Units.
In general, courses with a grade of D or higher will receive full credit in transfer.
For some degree programs, a course with a grade of D may not be used to satisfy specific requirements. A transfer student would be required to repeat a specified course on the same basis as a domestic UMKC student who earned a D in the equivalent course.
Coursework of any age will be accepted in transfer to satisfy general education requirements and electives. If transfer credit is more than 15 years old, or of a specific technical or scientific nature, students may be required to repeat courses that are part of a major or field concentration. Individual UMKC academic units may impose more restrictive coursework age requirements.

Do I Need to Submit Official Academic Records?
In many cases, you can wait until after you are admitted to submit official documents. However, we reserve the right to request official documents before issuing a decision (admit or deny). We will email you if we require official documents during the application process. You can see some common requests in the individual country information below.
You might be required to show your official transcripts, mark sheets, diplomas, and degree certificates after you are admitted. If any documents are required, they will be listed on your admission letter. Read your admission letter carefully to determine which documents we have requested from you.
Documents that you upload to your online application portal or send by email are not considered official. Please do not upload academic records again after you have been admitted.
If we have requested documents in your admission letter, you will receive a hold on your student account. This hold will prevent you from enrolling.
You will be allowed to enroll for your first semester using unofficial documents.
You will not be able to enroll in any future semester until we receive all the official, final documents we request on your admission letter.
If fraud is discovered in any documents submitted at any time to UMKC, the university will take appropriate action, up to and including denying or revoking admission at any time, even after UMKC studies have begun.

Book Your Flight
Kansas City International Airport, code MCI, is served by several large airlines including American Airlines, Delta Airlines, Southwest Airlines and United Airlines. Please make sure MCI is listed as your final destination.
Confirm your flight details at least three days before leaving your country.
Arrange to arrive in Kansas City no later than the Program Start/Begin Date, noted on your I-20 or DS-2019. You cannot arrive in the United States more than 30 days before your reporting date (for F-1 visa holders, this date is noted on your I-20 as Earliest Arrival Date).
Airlines have a maximum weight requirement per suitcase. You may want to ship some items to the university before you leave your country.
In Transit
Carry your passport, I-20 or DS-2019, admission letter, bank or funding verification and any other official or original documents like transcripts or diplomas with you.
Do not carry a large amount of cash. Have only enough to cover initial expenses such as taxi or bus fare, meals and housing for when you first arrive.
Never leave your luggage unattended.
On Arrival
Transportation
Taxi - The rates for transportation by taxi are $2.50 plus $2.10 per mile. Taxi service can be requested by phone by calling 816-243-2345 after you've arrived and collected your bags.
Ride Share - Ride share services such as Uber, Lyft, Iris, or zTrip can take you from the airport to your final destination in the Kansas City area. Rates vary based on mileage and time of day. Please be sure you have collected all of your bags prior to booking a ride with any app-based service.
Shuttle Services - Information about different private shuttle services available for reservation can be found on VisitKC's transportation page.
Metro Bus - Kansas City International Airport (MCI) is served by RideKC Route #229 (Boardwalk-KCI). RideKC buses are available for all riders for free through December 31, 2023. In 2024, bus fare information will be published on RideKC's Fares and Passes page.
Hotels
The average cost per night at a local hotel ranges from $125 to $200 USD. You can get a special rate if you call the hotel directly and tell them you are a UMKC student.

University housing does not come with admission.
You are not required to live on campus.
We recommend you make housing reservations before coming to Kansas City.

Financial Arrangements
Review all cost estimates listed on your UMKC I-20 or DS 2019.
These estimates are the minimum projections — actual costs vary.
The tuition amounts reflect full-time enrollment (12 credit hours per semester for undergraduate students and nine credit hours per semester for graduate students) for Fall and Spring semesters only. You may choose to enroll in more courses; however, that means higher total tuition costs.
Do not expect or depend on financial aid or part-time employment to meet your educational expenses. On-campus employment is competitive and is not guaranteed.
Payment of Fees
All fees are due and payable to the university at the date determined by the fee schedules. A minimum payment option is available for students unable to complete payment in full by the first due date of the semester. You may arrange a payment plan with the Cashier's Office.
The University does not require payment in full at enrollment. However, students are required to make monthly payments toward their outstanding balance over the course of the semester. You can view the payment schedule here.
If your bill for tuition and mandatory fees should be sent to a government sponsoring agency or institution, please submit your sponsor's financial guarantee letter to the Cashier's Office and to ISAO by the first payment deadline.
Questions about fees or your bill? Contact the Cashier’s Office.
Financial Aid and Awards
University-funded financial aid is limited, and the aid that does exist through the UMKC Financial Aid and Scholarship Office may only be eligible for US citizens and permanent residence through US Federal financial support. However, some of the UMKC competitive scholarships may be available for international students. Explore opportunities through the Financial Aid and Scholarship Office.
The most substantial financial support at UMKC is available as an academic scholarship awarded at the time of admission or for graduate students in the form of graduate assistantships, for which international students are not considered until after a semester or a year of study at UMKC.
International students awarded graduate assistantships that include teaching responsibilities must satisfactorily complete an English language screening and training program before undertaking teaching assignments. Learn more about funding opportunities through the School of Graduate Studies.

Check-in Session
Home / Admitted Students / Check-in Session
Now that you've been admitted and have made plans to attend UMKC as an F-1 or J-1 visa holder, you will need to register for a check-in session before you can enroll in classes.
ADMITTED STUDENTS
Student Visa
Pre-Arrival Information
Official Documents
Financial Information
Check-in Session
Student Housing
Health Insurance
UMKC Connections
Excited to enroll in classes at UMKC?
  You're almost ready. First, you have to register for a mandatory check-in session.
Attending a check-in session is a required part of maintaining your F-1 or J-1 visa status in the United States. During the session we will talk to you about the rules of your visa and attendance at UMKC.
Sign up for a session
Use your application portal username and password to sign up for a check-in session corresponding with your admission term using this link:
Check-In Session Pre-registration
Please note:
You must have obtained your visa in order to pre-register for a check-in session.
You may upload a copy of your visa to your application status page at any time, or you will have the option to upload it as part of the check-in pre-registration process.
Check-in sessions are not held virtually - you must be present in Kansas City to attend your check-in session. Please select a check-in date that is after your planned arrival to Kansas City.
Get ready for your session
Pre-registering for a session is just the first step. You must attend your registered session in person. Sessions are usually an hour and a half in length.
Plan to arrive at least 15 minutes before your session's scheduled start. Once the session has begun, latecomers will not be admitted and will need to reschedule for another date.
Check that you have successfully uploaded these documents to your application status page prior to your session:
Your passport or a copy of your passport biography page
Your ink-signed UMKC I-20 or DS-2019
Your I-94 (click here to access your I-94)
Please also have this information available at your session:
Your address in Kansas City
The name and phone number of an emergency contact
We are so glad you have chosen UMKC and can’t wait to meet you!

Home / Admitted Students / Student Housing
UMKC is located in a vibrant community near downtown Kansas City. The area around campus includes shopping centers, restaurants, city parks, museums, theaters and a variety of housing options.
ADMITTED STUDENTS
Student Visa
Pre-Arrival Information
Official Documents
Financial Information
Check-in Session
Student Housing
Health Insurance
UMKC Connections
On-campus Housing
Living on campus can be an important part of the American university experience. Plus, there are many benefits to on-campus housing.
Comfortable accommodations
Classes within walking distance or a short commute
Opportunities to make friends and become involved in campus activities
Reserve on-campus housing
When you sign a housing contract with the Residential Life office, you are signing a contract for the full academic year. If you are living in Kansas City for only one semester, you must notify Residential Life.
Required vaccination
All college students living on campus at public universities in Missouri are required to have the meningitis vaccination. The mandate was a provision of Senate Bill 716, signed into law July 10, 2014.
Students that fail to provide proof of the vaccine or an acceptable medical or religious waiver will not be allowed to occupy a residential space on campus. We recommend working with your physician or health-care provider to discuss next steps.
Off-Campus Housing
UMKC partners with CollegePads to provide you with an off-campus housing resource. In addition to finding your home, you can learn more about renting in the United States such as landlord/tenant laws and what to look for in your lease.

Explore off-campus options

Need Extra Time to Apply for Your Visa?
Sometimes it takes longer than expected to receive your travel documents, which may make it impossible for you to begin your studies at UMKC the semester for which you originally applied. If this has happened to you, you may request to start the next semester. Your request will be reviewed, and we will inform you if it is approved. 
Complete the deferral form
If your deferral request is approved, we will process it and send you new documentation from ISAO that lists your new reporting date. You will need to submit that documentation to obtain your visa.

You may defer your admission for up to two semesters. If you intend to delay your studies a full academic year, you will need to reapply to UMKC and submit an additional application fee.

International Student Affairs Office
Admitted Students
Home / Admitted Students
Congratulations on your admission to the University of Missouri – Kansas City! We are excited that you have selected UMKC to pursue your higher education goals. We look forward to welcoming you to Kansas City.
ADMITTED STUDENTS
Student Visa
Pre-Arrival Information
Official Documents
Financial Information
Check-in Session
Student Housing
Health Insurance
UMKC Connections
You've been accepted to UMKC. What are your next steps?
  1. Admission letter
You will receive an email letting you know that an update has been made to your application status. A link in that email will take you to your application status page where you'll find your official admission letter. If you are (or will be) an F-1 or J-1 student visa holder, this is also where you will find your supporting documents for your visa application. (It may take a couple of weeks after admission before your immigration documents will be uploaded and attached to your admission letter.)
Learn more about pre-arrival
  2. U.S. student visa
If you will need an F-1 or J-1 student visa to travel to the U.S. for your studies, your next step is to start the visa application process.
Learn more about your student visa
If you are experiencing a delay in scheduling an appointment for a visa, let us know so we can help with late arrival or admission deferral.
  Transferring your immigration record to UMKC
If you are already studying at another US institution on an F-1 visa, or if you entered the US on another school's I-20, you will need to complete the UMKC Transfer-in form and upload it as a document in your application portal.
Transfer-in form (PDF)


3. Check-in session
This step is only for students who will attend UMKC with an F-1 or J-1 student visa.
Once you have obtained your visa, you will need to pre-register for an immigration check-in session with our international advising team. Attendance at this in-person check-in session is required once you've arrived in the United States. You will need to register for your mandatory check-in session and submit a copy of your F-1 or J-1 visa in order to enroll in classes.
Learn more about the Check-In Session
  Submit these documents before you attend your scheduled session
Signed UMKC I-20 or DS-2019
A copy of your I-94 form (this will only be available to you after you've arrived to the U.S.)
Final, official transcripts and certificates of completion, if they have not yet been submitted
Please arrive for your session 15 minutes in advance. Late entry is not permitted.
  4. Enroll in classes
After you have registered for your check-in session, you will be eligible to meet with your academic advisor who will help you select classes. Enroll in classes through your academic advisor, the Office of the Registrar or through your Pathway student account.
  Undergraduate academic advising
New undergraduate students must complete a pre-enrollment survey in order to get enrolled in their first semester at UMKC. The link to this survey will be added to your Pre-Arrival Checklist within your application portal. For F-1 and J-1 students, this survey will only be available to you after you've registered for your check-in session and uploaded a copy of your student visa (step #3 above).
Undergraduates: Connect with Roo Advising
  Graduate academic advising
Most new UMKC students are required to meet with an advisor prior to registering for classes in their first semester. Depending on your major, you may be required to meet with your academic advisor prior to registering for classes each semester through your degree program.
Learn more about academic advising
  5. Attend International Student Orientation
All new international students are required to attend Orientation in their first semester. Orientation is typically held on the Thursday prior to the start of classes each fall and spring. You will receive more information about this exciting event as you get closer to the start of your first semester!
Registration will soon be available for Fall 2024 International New Student Orientation! this required orientation will be held on Thursday, August 15, 2024. If you are a new international student for Fall 2024, you will receive an email inviting you to register when the registration page is available.
  6. Submit Your Official Documents
You must submit your Official Documents (transcripts/degree certificates, official test scores as applicable) by the end of your first semester at UMKC. If you do not submit your Official Documents, you will not be able to enroll in your second semester.
We do not accept physical documents. Please read our Official Documents Policy for complete information on how to submit your documents.

Maintain Your Immigration Status
Our international student advisors are here to assist you in maintaining valid F-1 or J-1 student visa status, but it is ultimately your responsibility to comply with immigration regulations.
Federal regulations for your F-1 student visa
Status checklist (PDF)
How to stay in status (PDF)
Report any changes to us
Change in name
Change in address (update your local address in Pathway)
Change in visa
Early completion/graduation or change of major
Anything that may or will affect your visa or I-20/DS-2019, including taking a leave of absence for a semester, suspension or dismissal from your department.
Full-time enrollment
ISAO monitors enrollment. If you drop below the required credit hours at any point during the semester, we will send you two courtesy emails. If you do not answer the emails and take no action, we will be required to terminate your I-20/DS-2019 for unauthorized drop below a full course load, and you must leave the United States immediately or begin the process for reinstatement.
Bachelor and English-only students must enroll in a minimum of 12 credit hours every Fall and Spring semester. Only three of these credit hours can be online.
Master and Ph.D. students must enroll in a minimum of 9 credit hours every Fall and Spring semester. Only three of these credit hours can be online.
If you cannot enroll full-time, you must submit an FTE form and mark one of the category items.
The reduced course load/FTE form is now available in the ISAO Portal for current students. We will add access for new students at the start of the semester.
ISAO Portal
J-1 Student FTE Form (PDF)
Resources to help you maintain your status
Transfer to another school
Submit a copy of the official admission letter from your new school
Submit a transfer form, if they have one, from your new school
Tell us what date you would like your records released to your new school (If you are currently on OPT/STEM, your work authorization will automatically end the day we release your SEVIS records to your new school)
When your transfer has been processed you will receive an email from your ISAO advisor
Extend or renew your visa
Request to extend I-20 or DS-2019 (PDF)
Renewing your visa (PDF)
Change your status or apply for reinstatement
Send an email to isao@umkc.edu to start the conversation about changing your visa status or applying for reinstatement to F-1 status
Taking classes at another school?
Concurrent enrollment form (PDF)
Apply for or return from a leave of absence
Send an email to isao@umkc.edu to start the conversation about taking a leave of absence as an F-1 or J-1 visa holder
Request new initial I-20 to return from leave of absence (PDF)
Provide proof of sufficient funds
Affidavit of support (PDF)
Leaving UMKC?
Exit form (PDF)

Forms and Resources
Health Insurance
All students who are F-1 or J-1 visa holders attending UMKC are automatically enrolled in Anthem Student Advantage upon course registration each fall and spring semester.
Visit the ISAO Health Insurance Page
Insurance waivers
A small number of F-1 or J-1 students may be eligible for a health insurance waiver (such as if you are sponsored by your government). Please carefully review the Waiver Request Form to see if you meet one of the criteria. If you do, please complete the form and submit it to ISAO for review using the Secure Document Uploader in your Pathway Student Center.
UMKC Health Insurance Waiver Request Form (PDF)
Insurance waiver deadlines
Fall 2024 - September 4, 2024
Spring 2025 - January 29, 2025
Summer 2024 - June 13, 2024
Visiting a Doctor
Arrive early for your first appointment.
Fill out medical history paperwork before your appointment.
Your doctor may use language that you are unfamiliar with. It is okay to tell them that you do not understand.
Don't be afraid to ask questions.
UMKC resources
Roo Wellness
Student Disability Services
Off-campus resources
Find a doctor, hospital, or pharmacy that accepts Anthem
Specialists
Roo Wellness may refer you to a specialist. Do not visit a specialist without a referral.
Be prepared with your Anthem Student Advantage digital insurance card. It is available from anthem.com or in the Sydney Health mobile app.
Emergency services 
In case of emergency, call 911
Visit the emergency room only if your situation is an emergency, including serious bleeding or injury, ingestion of poison or drug overdose, broken bones, severe allergic reactions and any other health issue that is an immediate threat to someone’s well-being or life. Emergency services can be very expensive in the United States.
Eye care
Anthem Student Advantage does not include eye care.
There is an option to purchase vision insurance from an Anthem voluntary plan.
Dental care
Anthem Student Advantage does not include dental care.
There is an option to purchase dental insurance with an Anthem voluntary plan if you are a brand new student. If this is the case for you, please email isao@umkc.edu within the first two weeks of classes to inquire about dental insurance enrollment.
The UMKC School of Dentistry offers dental care at a reduced rate.

International Student Affairs Office
Students
Home / Current Students / Students
The J-1 visa is a nonimmigrant visa issued by the United States to exchange visitors participating in programs that promote cultural exchange, especially to obtain medical or business training within the United States.
CURRENT STUDENTS
International Advising
J-1 Student Visa
Maintain Your Status
Employment
Health Care
Forms and Resources
J-1 Visa for Students
J-1 students have the opportunity to study at American degree-granting, post-secondary accredited academic institutions, or participate in a student internship program that will fulfill the educational objectives of the students' degree program in their home country.
J-2 dependents
All J-1 visa holders are allowed to bring their spouse and children to the United States as long as the J-1 visa holder can show proof of funds to support them during their stay. Any married children or children 21 years or older will not be able to come over on a J-2 visa. Other family members such as parents and siblings will also not be able to come over on J-2 visa, but may want to look into a B-2 tourist visa.
If you would like to bring your spouse or children on J-2 visas, provide these documents.
Copy of passport photo page for each requested dependent
Copy of marriage certificate, if requesting a J-2 for your spouse
Copy of birth certificate for each J-2 child
Proof of funds (PDF) showing ability to support them ($7,000 for spouse, $5,900 for each child)
Duration of status
J-1 visitors may remain in the United States until the end of their exchange program, as specified on form DS-2019. Once the program ends, the visitor may remain in the United States for an additional 30 days, often referred to as the grace period, in order to prepare for departure from the country.
Full course of study
J-1 students must maintain full-time registration every Fall and Spring semester. Prior written authorization from an international student advisor is required to take a reduced course load. If students have to interrupt their studies for any reason, they must contact an advisor immediately.
Program extension
J-1 students are required to maintain the validity of their DS-2019 throughout the duration of their exchange programs in the United States. J-1 must apply to their program sponsors for an extension of their J-1 status before their current DS-2019 expires.
Early withdrawal
If a J-1 student is not able to complete an academic program, the student must notify an international student advisor for approval before withdrawing from the academic program.
Travel
J-1 students are advised to plan for international travel by first reviewing their DS-2019 immigration document.
Recommended documents for travel:
Passport
Immigration documents (DS-2019)
Travel signature on form DS-2019 (in most cases, no older than 12 months)
Concurrent enrollment
J-students are allowed only to be enrolled in 0 credit hours at UMKC during regular school holiday breaks. If a J-student wishes to be concurrently enrolled, the J-student must take an equal amount of credit hours at both UMKC and the other school.
Under-enrollment
Reasons J-students may be allowed to be under-enrolled:
Vacation
Medical problem
Bona fide academic reason - student must present their International Advisor with a written statement from their academic dean or advisor recommending the reduced course load and the reason why
Non-degree program - if the student is engaged full time in a prescribed course of study in a non-degree program of up to 24 months duration conducted by a post-secondary accredited educational institution
Academic training
Final term
Are you currently under-enrolled? Submit the J-1 FTE form (PDF)
Employment
Want to work off-campus before or after you graduate? Academic training information (PDF).
Economic hardship? Off-campus work authorization (PDF).
Already approved for economic hardship? Employer verification form (PDF)

International Student Affairs Office
J-1 Scholar Categories
Home / Exchange Visitors / J-1 Scholar Categories
EXCHANGE VISITORS
J-1 Exchange Scholar Categories
Hosting an Exchange Visitor
Exchange Visitor Responsibilities and Forms
Exchange Visitor (J-1) Nonimmigrant Visa Categories
What's the difference between scholars and students?
There are a variety of academic and professional experiences for exchange visitors.
Scholar or student classifications for exchange visitors
Category Definition J-visa type
J-1 short-term scholar Short-term scholars are limited to stay a maximum of six months. There are no extensions possible. Short-term scholars come to the United States for a short-term visit to lecture, observe, consult, train and demonstrate special skills. Scholar
J-1 professor A J-1 professor cannot be tenure track, and is considered to be a temporary employee. The primary purpose of J-1 professors is to teach, leacture, observe, consult and conduct research if permitted by the program sponsor. Scholar
J-1 research scholar Research scholars primarily conduct research, observe, consult and may also teach or lecture if permitted by the program sponsor. Like J-1 professors, J-1 research scholars have to stay in the United States for a minimum of three weeks, but can stay up to five years. Scholar
J-1 student intern A J-1 student intern is limited to a maximum stay of 12 months. UMKC will only host international students who are currently enrolled and pursuing a degree at a postsecondary academic institution outside the United States. J-1 student interns may not fill a permanent or long-term position of employment in the United States. Scholar
J-1 student UMKC is designated to host international students at the bachelor, master and doctoral levels. The 12-month bar applies to J-1 students who wish to return in the J-1 professor/research scholar category. Student
UMKC J-1 Exchange Visitor Visa Categories
Exchange student
Learn more at our J-1 Student Visa page.
Research scholar and professor
Minimum academic credentials - A bachelor’s degree or international equivalent
Program activities - Research, teaching and lecturing
Ineligible for tenure-track positions
Length of stay - At least three weeks but no more than five years
If previously in the United States in this J-category, please contact us to see if you are eligible to return. If you are subject to the 212e, 12- and 24-month bar, you may not be eligible.
Short-term scholar
Minimum academic credentials - A bachelor’s degree or international equivalent
Program activities - Lecturing, observing, consulting, training or demonstrating special skills
Length of stay - Maximum of six months with no option to extend
Cannot change status to another category while in the United States
Student intern
Minimum academic credentials - Enrolled in a degree program outside the United States
Program activities - Internship must fulfill an educational objective at home institution
Must plan to return to home institution to complete degree
Only available once per degree
Length of stay - Minimum of three weeks but no longer than 12 months, with no option to extend
Cannot change status to another category while in the United States

Apply to Host a Research Scholar, Professor, or Short-Term Scholar
The hosting faculty/department should complete our J-1 Scholar Request Form and return it via email to isaoadvisor@umkc.edu along with the supplemental documents listed on the form.
If the scholar is already in the US and wishes to transfer their immigration record to UMKC, ISAO will also need to receive a completed J-1 Transfer In Form.
Forms
J-1 Scholar Request Form (PDF)
Request for Extension of DS-2019 (PDF)
J-1 Transfer In Form (PDF)
J-1 Transfer Out Form (PDF)
Out-of-Country Form (PDF)
  Apply to Host a Student Intern
We are currently updating the process by which UMKC departments invite student interns to Kansas City. Email us if you have questions regarding the process or forms.
Step 1. ISAO determines eligibility 
Completed at least three months before the date the department wishes to invite a student intern to UMKC.
The UMKC department email us the Prospective J-1 Student Intern forms.
Eligibility Verification Request (PDF)
English Proficiency (PDF)
DS-7002 Information (PDF)
Our J-1 scholar advisor reviews documents and either approves eligibility or suggests other visa option.
If student intern is approved, advisor prepares Form DS-7002 and sends to UMKC department.
Step 2. Department collects student intern application documents
Completed at least two months prior to student intern’s requested start date at UMKC.
Department prepares invitation and offer letter for prospective student intern
Prospective student intern submits documents to the host department
Signed DS-7002 (sent to student intern after department faculty has signed and dated)
Proof of finances (PDF) (Affidavit of Support (PDF), if student intern will be supported by family)
Copy of passport information/photo page
Home Institution Verification (PDF)
Dependent documents, if applicable
Step 3. We prepare official student intern invitation packet
Please allow two to four weeks.
Advisor will review all submitted documentation and make copies for ISAO records
Advisor will prepare DS-2019 for Student-Intern and include it in a packet along with other helpful information for student’s visa application and arrival to UMKC
ISAO will notify department by email when invitation packet is ready for pick-up
Step 4. Department mails invitation packet to student intern
Completed at least one month before student intern’s expected start date at UMKC.
Department is responsible for mailing completed invitation packet to the student-intern
Student intern must receive the original DS-2019 to apply for their visa
Student intern must also have a copy of their DS-7002 for their visa application

International Student Affairs Office
Exchange Visitor Responsibilities and Forms
Home / Exchange Visitors / Exchange Visitor Responsibilities and Forms
EXCHANGE VISITORS
J-1 Exchange Scholar Categories
Hosting an Exchange Visitor
Exchange Visitor Responsibilities and Forms
Responsibilities for All Exchange Visitors
General
Maintain health insurance, including any J-2 dependents, for entire duration of program 
Primary purpose must be full-time, temporary research, observation, lecture/teach, consult or to participate in seminars, workshops, conferences and other types of educational or professional activities
Demonstrate and maintain sufficient funds (PDF) for period of program
Demonstrate adequate English proficiency (PDF)
Update Pathway with changes to your name, visa, address and contact information within 10 days of any change
Let us know if you have been in the United States within the past 24 months
Grace period
After the end of your program, you will have a 30-day grace period. During this period you are not allowed to work or enroll in courses. You may travel within the United States, but once you leave the United States during your grace period, your visa will end and you will not be able to re-enter on it.
Health insurance
Your health insurance must cover your entire duration of stay stated on your DS-2019. You may purchase health insurance once you arrive. That means you must have coverage from your start date to your end date — it cannot be off by even one day.
Health insurance must meet these requirements.
$100,000 medical benefits per accident/illness
$25,000 repatriation of remains
$50,000 medical evacuation
$500 maximum deductible per accident/illness
You must bring with you one of these documents.
Proof of insurance and policy from U.S.-based insurance company
Proof of insurance and policy in English and 24-hour phone number based in the United States
Already have health insurance?
Submit confirmation (PDF)
Financial documents
Applicants must show proof of funds sufficient to support themselves and any dependents (PDF) during their stay in the United States.
Financial documents should be dated within the last year and should be liquid funds (checking or savings account) or in the form of scholarship letters.
J-2 dependents
All J-1 visa holders are allowed to bring their spouse and children to the United States as long as the J-1 visa holder can show proof of funds to support them during their stay. Any married children or children 21 years or older will not be able to come over on a J-2 visa. Other family members such as parents or siblings will also NOT be able to come over on J-2 visa, but may want to look into a B-2 tourist visa.
If you would like to bring your spouse or children on J-2 visas, please provide these documents.
Copy of passport photo page of each requested dependent
Copy of marriage certificate with English translation if requesting a J-2 for your spouse
Copy of birth certificate with English translation for each J-2 child
Proof of funds showing ability to support them ($6,700 per dependent spouse/child[ren])
Forms
I-94 Form
Request to Add J-2 Dependent After Exchange Visitor Has Arrived (PDF)
J-2 Work Authorization Instructions and Information (PDF)
Exit Form (PDF)
UMKC Guide to Living in Kansas City (PDF)

International Student Affairs Office
Tax Information
Home / Current Students / Employment / Tax Information
EMPLOYMENT
Curricular Practical Training (CPT)
Optional Practical Training (OPT)
Tax Information
Who has to file tax returns?
All international students and scholars who were present in the United States for any duration of time in the previous calendar year are required to file tax returns with the Internal Revenue Service (IRS), regardless of whether or not you worked.
What if I didn't work or receive any income?
You are still obliged to file Form 8843 with the IRS, just for being present in the United States in the calendar year 2023.
Deadline for the 2023 tax filing season: April 15, 2024
Why file a tax return?
Stay tax compliant - Failing to file may impact the status of your current visa and make future U.S. visa applications difficult
Avoid penalties – If you miss the deadline you may face late filing penalties
You may be owed a tax refund – Last year, the average Federal refund received by eligible students was more than $1,000
Sprintax
Understanding the U.S. tax system and filing a tax return can be a confusing experience for any student. To make things easier for you, we have teamed up with Sprintax, an online tool specifically designed for international students and scholars.
We provide free Federal and 8843 filing, but if you are required to file a state tax return, you will be notified in the system and can choose to self-pay to file your state tax return.
Get started with Sprintax
Click here to register with Sprintax
Complete the online questionnaire.
Your Sprintax discount code will be sent to your UMKC email account. Enter this code in the box on the “Review your order” page.
Sprintax will prepare your tax return and check if you are due a refund.
Print, sign and mail your documents to the IRS.
Documents you will need to prepare your taxes
Passport
Entry and exit dates for current and all past visits to the United States
Tax forms
W-2 – if you worked on-campus or for a U.S. employer, the W-2 reports your annual wages and amount of taxes withheld from your paycheck
1042-S and/or 1099 – if you received a scholarship, fellowship grant or other award, you may receive this form, which typically comes from the university payroll department
Visa/immigration status information, including I-20 (for F-visa holders) or DS-2019 (J-visa holders)
Social Security Number (SSN) or Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN). If you do not have an ITIN, Sprintax can help you get one!
If you are using Sprintax for State tax return preparation only, you will need the federal tax return you already prepared
More information from Sprintax
Sprintax Instructions 2023 (PDF)
Sprintax Brochure 2023 (PDF)
Sprintax videos on YouTube
Sprintax blog
  Other Preparation Services
There are several other private tax preparation services available, such as TurboTax and H&R Block, but they charge to file your taxes and may not be able to provide you with the correct forms as a non-resident. We do not recommend using these services unless you know you qualify to file as a resident.
  The Internal Revue Services (IRS) is the tax collection agency for the United States
IRS website
  Have Questions?
If you have any questions at all about your taxes, from "Am I required to file taxes?" to "Can someone help me with Sprintax?", please direct your questions to the University of Missouri Nonresident Tax Office. You can email them directly at nonrestax@umsystem.edu
DISCLAIMER: International Student Affairs Office (ISAO) and UMKC are not permitted to assist any student/scholar with any IRS tax form preparation or tax-related questions. The information provided on this page is provided for your benefit. Any questions or concerns should be directed to Sprintax, a certified tax preparer, or a local IRS field office.

Exchange Visitors
Home / Exchange Visitors
The work- and study-based Exchange Visitor program promotes global understanding through cultural and educational exchanges. We welcome exchange visitors from around the world and are committed to enriching their professional development and academic goals.
EXCHANGE VISITORS
J-1 Exchange Scholar Categories
Hosting an Exchange Visitor
Exchange Visitor Responsibilities and Forms
Exchange Visitor (J-1) Nonimmigrant Visa
The Exchange Visitor (J-1) nonimmigrant visa category is for individuals approved to participate in work- and study-based exchange visitor programs. Participants in the Exchange Visitor program are expected to return to their home countries after they have completed their programs to share their exchange experiences. 
View eligibility and fees
Learn about the program
What documentation do I need?
Form DS-2019 is a Certificate of Eligibility for Exchange Visitor (J-1) status. When you have been offered acceptance into an exchange program at UMKC, an immigration advisor in the International Student Affairs Office will issue a DS-2019. Upon receipt of the DS-2019, you can begin the application process for the J-1 visa and the nearest U.S. embassy or consulate in your country of residence.
Pay I-901 SEVIS fee

International Student Affairs Office
Kuwait
Home / Sponsored Students / Kuwait
We make it a priority to assist our Kuwaiti-sponsored students and to make the transition to life at UMKC and in the United States as easy as possible.
SPONSORED STUDENTS
Kuwait
Oman
Saudi Arabia
Sponsor Information
Welcome to UMKC!
Congratulations on receiving a scholarship from the Embassy of Kuwait! Because you are sponsored by the Embassy of Kuwait, there are specific instructions to follow and requirements to meet.
Financial guarantees
A financial guarantee from the Embassy of Kuwait is required for us to bill the embassy for your tuition and fees. Typically, your advisor at the Embassy of Kuwait will send your financial guarantee directly to our sponsored student officer. If you are receiving bills from the Cashiers Office saying you have unpaid tuition, request a copy of your financial guarantee and email it to our sponsored student officer, Morgan Ramsey.
Check-in
When you arrive in Kansas City, you will need to schedule a check-in session through Online Services. Bring passports, student visa, I-20s, I-94s and a local address to your check-in session.
Consent form
A Consent Form (PDF) is required for sponsored students because UMKC needs permission from the student to issue student information to a sponsoring agency. You will be asked to complete a consent form at your check-in session.
International Student Orientation
The mandatory International Student Orientation is usually held on the Tuesday before classes start. Failure to attend orientation will result in a hold on your account, which prevents you from enrolling in future semesters. The only way to remove this hold is to attend another orientation.
English evaluation
Students who are conditionally admitted to UMKC will be required to take an English evaluation at the Applied Language Institute upon arrival. This evaluation will determine what level of ESL courses might be required.
Health insurance
All new international students are automatically enrolled in UMKC’s student health insurance program. Because Kuwaiti-sponsored students and their dependents receive insurance through the Embassy of Kuwait, you do not need to have this student insurance. To avoid being automatically charged for UMKC health insurance, please complete a Health Insurance Waiver (PDF) and turn it in during your check-in session.
Enrollment
When you have completed your check-in session and English evaluation, if needed, you can meet with an academic advisor to begin selecting courses. It is your responsibility to make sure you are enrolled full time (undergraduate: 12 credit hours, graduate: nine credit hours).
Kuwaiti-sponsored students are not permitted to enroll in online, evening, weekend, accelerated PACE or Arabic language courses without special permission from the Embassy of Kuwait. If an academic advisor discusses online courses during the course selection process, it is your responsibility to explain to the academic advisor that you are unable to enroll in online courses due to scholarship restrictions.
Late enrollment fees are not covered by the Embassy of Kuwait.
Please review the Kuwait MOHE Rules and Regulations for more information.
Change of major
If you wish to change your major you must first get approval from your advisor at the Embassy of Kuwait. If your advisor at the Embassy of Kuwait approves the change of major, you will receive a new financial guarantee which you must submit to us.
Student housing
There are a variety of living arrangements available to students. If you would like to learn more about on-campus housing, please review the information provided by Residential Life.
